Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A brief encounter in the corridor leads to a simple hello and smile.
Story: I was heading out for dinner with my friends when I saw my younger sister standing by the door, looking hopeful. She’d been hinting all week that she wanted to join us, and I knew including her would mean a lot to her. As her brother, I wanted to build that mutual respect, to show her she was welcome in my world. But just as I was about to invite her, our neighbor Mrs. Lee stepped into the corridor. She smiled and greeted me warmly, expecting the usual friendly exchange. I felt the pressure to be polite and not keep her waiting, but my sister was watching, waiting for my invitation. My mind raced—should I pause to chat with Mrs. Lee, as a good neighbor should, or quickly invite my sister along before she lost hope? The expectations from both sides pressed in on me, and I stood there, torn, caught between the roles of brother and neighbor, unsure which demand to meet first.
